titleStmt.title: Aratea Digital
Description of Vatican, BAV, Vat. lat. 643

editionStmt.edition: Digital edition according to TEI P5

msDesc.head:
TITLE
Austria , Melk (?), s. XII
De signis coelis (readction)

msItem.rubric: De stella veneris et mercurii saturni iouis et martis
msItem.incipit: Itaque stella ueneris et mercurii hoc a superioribus tribus planetarum stellis differunt
msItem.explicit: et idcirco longiores ethercas metas peragit

msItem.author: (Ps.) Bede
msItem.title: De apsidibus planetarum
msItem.incipit: Circulus zodiacus qui XII signis constat

msItem.note: Text on the simultaneous rising and setting of the constellations.
msItem.incipit: Ariete oriente duabus horis. occidit libra
msItem.explicit: superioris zodiaci sagittarius inferioris optinet gemini.

msItem.note: How to calculate the rising of the zodiacal signs.
msItem.quote: Hortum signorum XII qualibet diei uel noctis hora quisque liquido deprehensurus est si a KL octobris horas dierum ac noctium usque ad eam quam si proposuit colligens per XXIIIIor metiatur et quos excreuerit diuidat quem ad modum subiecta instruit formula. Si I aut duo remanserunt oritur libra. Si III aut IIII scorpio. Si V aut VI sagittarius. Si VIII aut VIII capricornus. Si VIIII aut X aquarius. Si XI aut XII pisces. Si XIII aut XIIII aries. Si XV aut XVI taurus. Si XVII aut XVIII gemini, Si XVIIII aut XX cancer. Si XXI aut XXII leo. Si XXIII aut XXIIII uirgo.

msItem.note: Computistical texts: on the eclipse, De incremento saltus lunae, De concordia solis et lunae, embolismi etc.
msItem.incipit: Deliquium Solis contigisse fertur anno ab incarnatione domini DCCCoVIII Quicquid ergo inde aut abcessit

msItem.title: De solis et lunae defectus
msItem.incipit: Deliquium Solis contigisse fertur anno ab incarnatione domini DCCCVIII...
msItem.explicit: ... quod quotiens contigerit totiens eclypsin non defecturam

msItem.title: Argumentum ad inveniendum IQSVM
msItem.incipit: Annis ab initio mundi per senarium diuisis...

msItem.title: De incremento saltus lunae
msItem.incipit: Primo sciendum est quod in toto decennouenali circulo unus dies de saltu lunae accrescat
msItem.explicit: ... et sextans id eset sexta pars momenti.

msItem.title: De concordia soli et lunae
msItem.explicit: ...possunt VIIII hore lunares cum quinque diebus solaribus concordare

msItem.title: De quibus embolismi menses et bissextiles dies adimplentur
msItem.incipit: Luna igitur cotidie et cetera transit XIII partes et horas VIII...
msItem.explicit: ... Hec ratio subtilissima est et ualde necessatia et maxima labori undecumque ab auctoribus collecta et ad quam vernenda mentis acies purganda.

msItem.incipit: Non est pretermittendum cum dixit de natura rerum cur non etiam de natura temporum uel de ratione rerum et ratione temporum dixit
msItem.explicit: idest CCma XXXV pars XLVII semis momentorum.

msItem.note: Computistical texts on the epacts and regulares solis.
msItem.title: Quid est[or sint?] epacta solis et regulares solis
msItem.incipit: Dum audis epactas lune aetates lune per singulos annos intellige...
msItem.explicit: ...uel quot dies usque ad Kalendas futuri mensis supersunt

msItem.note: 12-line verse on the course of the planets within the zodiac and their distance from earth.
msItem.explicit: Proxima telluri dum curris candida phebe
msItem.note: ed. Walther, 2200, Schaller 1977, 1725; Baehrens, Poetae Latini minores, vol. 5, p. 350, lin. 15-351, lin 9)

msItem.explicit: lactuces non comedat nec in balneum calidum ingrediatur.

msItem.note: 122-line verse on the zodiac and the months
msItem.incipit: Nomina signorum quis clauditur astriger orbis
msItem.explicit: Versus qui restant qui uult in fine requirat.

msItem.title: De signis coelis (redaction incl AL)
msItem.incipit: Quodam tamen multa dicunt et alii alter narasse
msItem.decoNote: Illustrations of the constellations, diagram of the zodiac, the moon and the sun in chariots and a map of the celestial zones. The stars are marked in red according to the positions stated in the text. The illustrated disctinguish between brighter and fainter stars: the one referred to as splendior are circles filled with a red crosses on a black background, while those labelled obscura are filled in dull dark-red.

history.provenance: From the 18th c. was in the Vatican
